Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Ateam of biodiversity researchers tested the hypothesis that urban golf courses
encourage more native insect diversity than urban parks. They used grid sampling, setting
up 25 insect CO, traps within each site. CO, traps anaesthetise the insects so they can be
counted, after which the insects recover and are released.
Index of Diversity (SID) was calculated by the researchers, to compare the
native insect diversity of the two sites.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The researchers used grid sampling in their study.
Explain why grid sampling was used, rather than transect sampling. Give one
example of when transect sampling could be used in preference to grid sampling.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Use the figures in the table below and the space provided to calculate SID for the
golf course.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
SID for insects within the urban park was calculated as 0.56.
Using these figures, compare the insect diversity of the urban park and the golf
course, as indicated by the SID.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The researchers found that ground-nesting native bees are not found in much of the
urban landscape because it is dominated by exotic flowering plants and is highly
managed by humans. Golf courses, on the other hand, contain 'rough' areas that are
dominated by native vegetation with minimal human intervention.
Using this information, suggest two reasons why ground-nesting native bees might
survive on golf courses but not in urban parks.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: Give two reasons why it is important to maintain insect populations in ecosystems.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
One criticism of insect CO, traps as a method is that they are less effective at
capturing smaller insects. :
Explain how this limitation would have reduced the validity of this study.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Evaluate whether the study adheres to ethical guidelines for undertaking scientific
research.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Australian sea lions (Neophoca cinerea) are sea- and land-dwelling mammals and are only found
around the western and southern coasts of Australia. They are camivorous, consuming ocean fish and
shellfish. They hunt in the ocean and breed on land. Sixty-six breeding colonies have been identified,
with 28 in Western Australia and 38 in South Australia.

Content:
The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) classifies the Australian
sea lion as endangered.
Explain how the range of the sea lion (refer to Figure 1) would have contributed to this
classification.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Would the management teams focused on the sea lion species be aiming to have the
classification changed to 'vulnerable' or 'critically endangered'?
Explain your choice of classification.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: Outline why the sea lions are at particular risk from a new infectious disease.

Inaddition to hunting, the sea lions are under threat from over-exploitation of their
prey, and from a reduction in their land-based habitat due to erosion.
Choose one of these threats and suggest a management strategy that wil help to
restore the range and/or population of the sea lions. Explain how this strategy will
counter the specific threat you have chosen.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Another possible threat to the sea lions is polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS),
persistent organic pollutants in the environment. PFAS have been reported to cause
cancer and reproductive and developmental defects.
Between 2017 and 2020, scientists measured the concentrations of PFAS in liver
samples from 28 young sea lion pups from colonies in South Australia. Scientists
wished to investigate causes of the decline in sea lion numbers. Samples were taken :
from fresh carcasses at various sites and the scientists found high PFAS levels in
all samples.
Identify the limitations of this investigation and explain how these limitations impacted
on the scientists' ability to draw conclusions about what may be causing a decline in
sea lion numbers.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The Wirangu People, who are the traditional custodians of the Chain of Bays area
in South Australia, hold the Australian sea lion in significant esteem as their spiritual
totem.
Explain why it is important to protect the sea lion in terms of cultural services.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Apublic reserve is located in a creek valley that was a site for gold mining that began in
the 1850s. Mining declined significantly by the 1920s but still continues in the wider region
today. The waste from processes used to extract gold from the mined rock are called mine
tailings. Tailings can contain high concentrations of harmful heavy metals such as arsenic,
lead and mercury. Mine tailings are now regulated as part of any mining development
licence; however, in the early mining period these legal protections did not exist.
This public reserve is currently used by local residents. Preliminary investigation of the
site identified 110 flora species (41% were indigenous plants and 59% were exotic) and
49 different fauna species. Some significant remnant habitat trees exist within the reserve
and one rare local plant species was found (although these were planted by the local
Landcare group).
Amining company proposes to excavate, from this creek valley reserve, 3.5 million tonnes
of tailings material that covers the natural ground surface. This material will be processed
to recover gold, mercury and industrial sand.
The plan is for vegetation to be cleared from the reserve and the tailings removed
(between one to two metres in depth). The material will be moved to a nearby processing
area and storage facility on private land. The proposal aims to then progressively restore
the original landscape, the indigenous ecology, and cultural and hydrological values of the
creek valley over a five-year period.
Before the proposal can proceed, the Minister for Planning has decided that an
environmental effects statement (EES) must be prepared for consideration. An EES wil
analyse the potential effects of the project on the environment and the means of avoiding,
minimising or managing possible adverse effects.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Evaluate whether the proposal to extract gold and heavy metals from the tailings
material, and eventually restore the public reserve, demonstrates the sustainability 73
principles of 'efficiency of resource use' and 'conservation of biodiversity and
ecological integrity'.
Justify your answer by including an explanation of these principles in the context of :
the proposal.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Does the extraction of gold in this region prior to the 1920s demonstrate the
sustainability principle of 'intergenerational equity'? Explain.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
How does the environmental effects statement (EES) help to support responsible
decision-making?

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Given that a detailed environmental assessment of the site has not been completed,
kS explain how the 'precautionary principle' should be applied to any proposal to mine
H the tailings.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Ifthe proposal were to go ahead, identify one beneficial impact on the lithosphere and
one harmful impact on the hydrosphere that may occur.

Content:
Beneficial impact on lithosphere
Harmful impact on hydrosphere .

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The impact of rising temperatures and the increasing frequency of heatwaves is a growing
challenge for urban areas. Rising temperatures particularly affect cities because of the
'urban heat island effect', in which urban areas are warmer than the surrounding rural land.
This is a result of the presence of roads, pathways, buildings and dark roofs that absorb
heat more than green (e.g. gardens and parks) and blue (e.g. rivers and lakes) surfaces.
With the urban heat island effect, temperatures in our urban areas can be 1-7 °C higher
than in surrounding areas.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that, 'in urban
areas, observed climate change has caused adverse impacts on human health,
livelihoods and key infrastructure. Hot extremes have intensified in cities
(high confidence)'.
The IPCC provided a rating of confidence as 'high confidence' for the above statement
in 2023.
Explain what is meant by 'confidence rating' and what the rating is based on.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Increasingly, architects will include green roofs and green walls, also known as
[J vertical gardens, in their designs. Green roofs and vertical gardens are buildings
: covered in plants.
Explain why this would be classified as an application of new technology to impact
£ greenhouse gas levels.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
In 2018, the City of Melbourne adopted strategies for vertical and rooftop greening as
part of its Green Our City Strategic Action Plan. The aim is to increase the number of
high-quality green roofs and walls in the City of Melbourne as part of the city's future
planning. These green roofs and walls can reduce the impact of the urban heat island
effect by helping to cool the surrounding area.
Explain how the above strategy is an example of an adaptation option and not
mitigation option to manage climate change at a local level.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
According to the 2022 Global Status Report for Buildings and Construction, the building
and construction sector contributes to approximately 34% of the global energy demand
and 37% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Currently, the most common building
material is concrete. Hempcrete is a plant-based material. While it cannot replace concrete
for al building purposes, it does provide an option for some non-structural uses.
Hempcrete is made from hemp shiv (the woody inner portion of the plant stalk), lime and
water, while concrete is made from cement, sand, gravel or stone, and water.
Source: 'Opportunities & challenges of hempcrete as a building material for construction: An overview',
Materials Today: Proceedings <sciencedirect.com>

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
As more homes install solar panels on their roofs, managing the distribution of electricity
becomes a challenge. Currently, a project is investigating if using a virtual power plant
(VPP) can help to regulate the energy produced and used by households.
The VPP does not generate its own electricity. However, it will remotely turn off household
appliances, such as hot water heaters and pool pumps, when they are not required.
will also turn on electricity-generating resources, such as home solar panels, when more
electricity is required. The aim is to reduce demand in peak periods and better manage
overall supply and demand for electricity.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: Explain why solar power is categorised as a renewable energy source.

Use the following information to answer parts d and e.
An open-cut coal mine was closed in 2012 and has since undergone rehabilitation.
The following measures were taken:
Topsoil was spread across the area; physical erosion-control measures were
implemented; tree hollows, woody debris and logs were incorporated into the landscape;
and nesting boxes were installed.
- Native seeds were sown and more sensitive plants were transplanted as tube-stock trees.
Revegetation with native flora was monitored and invasive weeds were removed to
ensure the success of the rehabilitation process.
The main hole created by the mine was allowed to fill with rainwater and run-off. It will
eventually flow into the nearby creek.
Recent monitoring of the site has found seven threatened species living in the area,
including the powerful owl and squirrel glider.

Subject: Environmental Science

strategy used by the coal mine.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The southern pygmy perch (Nannoperca australis) has been successfully reintroduced to
Bendigo Creek, where it was formerly locally extinct. This fish grows 6-8 cm in length and
occupies wetland habitat, using dense reeds and driftwood for protection from predators
and for breeding. These fish play a vital role in the Bendigo Creek ecosystem. They
consume mosquito larvae, providing a natural method of pest control. They also act as
key food source for numerous native freshwater fish and waterbird species.
Local extinction of the Bendigo Creek perch population occurred during the mid-19th
century. This was due to habitat loss and degradation, competition from invasive fish
species, prolonged drought and excessive water extraction for agriculture.
Following the reintroduction of the southern pygmy perch in 2020, populations of this fish
are now thriving in Bendigo Creek.
Due to copyright restrictions,
this material is not supplied.
Source: iNaturalist, <www.inaturalist.org/taxa/209236-Nannoperca-australis>

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The conservation status of the southern pygmy perch has recently been upgraded to
'near threatened' by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
State which conservation category the perch would most likely have belonged to
before conservation efforts.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: Explain why competition from an invasive species is a threat to the perch.

Two management strategies undertaken before the successful reintroduction of the
perch to the area were restoration of habitat and captive breeding.
Describe an action that could have been taken in each strategy. 

Conservationists performed genetic analysis of the perch population in 2022, two

population to that of the original population.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Using this example, explain why the conservationists collected data on the original

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Ten years ago, a farming family bought an 8 hectare section of a former cattle property and
converted it into an organic market garden. Their aim was to produce mainly herbs and
vegetables, as well as native fruits and seeds.
This family now supplies produce to three local markets and several restaurants within
a 10 km radius of the farm. The prices of their organic herbs, vegetables and fruits are
higher than the prices for produce grown using conventional methods. However, the local
community has supported the organic market garden because of its interest in native foods
and the belief that the use of chemicals in food production can be harmful to health.
A creek runs along the northern boundary of the market garden. The land for the cattle
property was cleared more than 150 years ago and, over time, this led to poor soil quality,
erosion of the creek banks and a build-up of sediment in the creek. The productivity of the
cattle farm declined. The farming family has worked with local environmental groups to
revegetate the creek valley with endemic plants.
As organic farmers, the family has used a variety of natural methods to improve soil health,
for example:
•	 using naturally occurring fertilisers such as green compost and animal manures (rather
than industrially manufactured fertilisers)
•	 minimising water use to irrigate the plants
•	 implementing biological pest control methods (rather than using chemical pesticides)
•	 planting legumes, which add nitrogen to the soil.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Does the conversion to organic farming from cattle grazing demonstrate the
sustainability principles of 'efficiency of resource use' and 'intergenerational equity'?
Justify your response by explaining the meaning of each term in the context of the
development of the organic market garden from land previously used for cattle grazing.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Discuss the values and priorities that have influenced responsible decision-making by
the farming family in the organic market garden's development.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
With reference to the change in land use from cattle grazing to organic market
gardening, use the concept of cost-benefit analysis to complete the table below. Give
one example for each blank cell in the table.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
A local restaurant owner suggests that, by setting up an organic market garden to
grow and sell produce for the farming family's income, the family is demonstrating an
anthropocentric focus.
Evaluate this viewpoint in the context of the change to land use at the organic
market garden that has occurred over the 10 years. Make the meaning of the term
'anthropocentrism' clear in your response.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The Kennaook/Cape Grim (KCG) air monitoring station is located on the north-west tip of Tasmania.
The purpose of the KCG station is to take many individual measurements of key indicators of global air
quality, such as greenhouse gases and ozone-depleting substances. The KCG station's unique location
allows for local sources of pollution to be avoided by only taking measurements at times when winds
blow in from across the Southern Ocean. Avoiding local pollution in this way allows for changes in global
air quality to be measured over time.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Cotton is one of Australia's most valuable exports, with 90% of cotton grown in Australia
being sold overseas. Cotton is an annual crop, with the planting season usually beginning
in September and harvesting in autumn. The flower of the cotton plant is harvested to
produce fibres for clothing and other textiles.
Source: zcebeci/Shutterstock.com
Cotton has an optimal growing temperature of 28 °C ± 2 °C. Temperatures below 11
can negatively affect seedling growth. In addition, extreme high temperatures can cause
flower loss, reducing crop yield.
Climate scientists are investigating the potential opportunities and risks of climate
change for cotton farmers. In 2024, historical climate modelling found that between 1960
and 2020 there was:
•	 a decrease in the average number of early season cold shocks
•	 a decrease in days from planting until first flowering
•	 an increase in average growing season temperatures
•	 an increase in the frequency of high-temperature days
•	 an increase in evaporation and transpiration rates
•	 no significant change in seasonal rainfall.
Reference: K Broughton, C Nunn and M Bange, 'The here and now of climate change: Climatic trends throughout
Australian cotton regions and implications for the growing season', Field Crops Research, vol. 315, 1 July 2024

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The optimal growing temperature for cotton indicates a degree of uncertainty of ± 2
Describe what is meant by the term 'uncertainty' and what it suggests about the ideal
growing temperature for cotton.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Based on the information provided, suggest two potential future risks to the cotton
industry. 

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The Northern Territory Government has been trialling cotton crop production in several
regions. Over 9700 hectares of cotton were planted in the 2023-2024 growing season
in the Northern Territory. A group of local Aboriginal people have expressed concerns
about the change in land use of the area.
Explain the importance of Aboriginal people's perspectives in the Northern Territory
Government's decision to allow cotton crop production to be trialled in the territory.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
In 2022, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) indicated with high
confidence that sustainable land management practices can contribute to reducing
the negative impacts of climate change.
Outline what the IPCC's confidence rating suggests about the importance of
sustainable land management practices for cotton growers.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Cape Byron Power in New South Wales is one of Australia's largest commercial biomass
energy suppliers. The company runs two 30 MW biofuel power plants, which mainly burn
the waste products from wood residues and sugarcane milling. Energy crops, such as
dedicated plantation forests, are also grown specifically for biomass fuel. Combined, the
power plants supply sufficient energy to power approximately 60 000 homes.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The biofuel used has an energy content of 15 MJ/kg. When 1000 kg of biofuel is
burned, 5250 MJ of electricity is produced.
Calculate the efficiency of the biofuel power plant. Show your working.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Compare the environmental impact of using biomass energy to that of using coal in
terms of the carbon cycle.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Identify one risk of growing the energy crops for biomass fuel and describe the
potential impact this might have on the local environment.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
The Northern Rivers region of New South Wales has a population of approximately
300 000 people.
Evaluate whether biomass energy is a suitable source to meet the base load energy
requirements of this region.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Proposals have been made to introduce the use of nuclear power in Australia. The plans
include constructing several nuclear power plants across the country.

Content: Circle the correct classifications for nuclear energy in terms of its source and renewability.

Content:
It is claimed that nuclear energy will provide cheaper energy to the consumer due to
lower running costs across the working life span of a nuclear reactor. A small nuclear
reactor can produce the same amount of electricity as a large wind farm
approximately 300 MW.

nuclear reactor and a wind farm across their working life spans.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Use the data provided to calculate and compare the overall cost of each form of
power generation over 80 years.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Insulation is a material that can be used to block or slow the flow of heat into and out of a house,
keeping it warmer in winter and cooler in summer. Insulation materials are given an R value, which is
measure of the rate of heat loss or gain. The higher the R value, the better the material insulates.
A class of students wanted to compare five insulation materials. They were provided with R values from
manufacturers. They obtained five identical boxes made of plywood with tightly fitting, removable lids.
They attached pieces of insulation of equal thickness to the sides and bottoms of each box, including
the lid, but left one box without any insulation coverage.
The following table provides information about the different insulation materials that were used by the
students in the experiment.
Box
number
Insulation material
Known R value of material
used in experiment
plain plywood
box (no additional
insulation material)
fibreglass batt
natural wool batt
rockwool batt
polystyrene board

Inside each of the five boxes, the students placed a beaker containing 500 mL of water
that had just boiled. They then inserted the temperature probe into the water (attached by
a wire to a digital temperature display outside the box) and immediately placed the lid on
each box. The diagram below shows the experimental set-up.
88.4
box lid
(covered with insulation)
digital temperature display
temperature probe
beaker filled with 500 mL boiling water
outer layer of insulation
plywood box
The students plan to record the temperature of each beaker of water at the start of the
experiment and then every 2 minutes for a total of 30 minutes.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: State a suitable hypothesis for the experiment conducted by the students.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content: Identify the dependent variable for this experiment.

Justify your response.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Identify a systematic error associated with the use of a temperature probe and
suggest how this error could be prevented.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
Explain why the use of insulation materials with a higher R value in houses helps
reduce personal energy consumption.

Subject: Environmental Science
Content:
A builder plans to renovate a home that already has some roof and wall insulation.
Suggest how the builder could maximise the insulation efficiency of the home in terms
of heating and cooling.
